CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: In the solid state , the planarity effect and interchain stacking of PffBB-n caused the bathochromic shift of the absorption cut - off to ∼ 780 nm , corresponding to a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.61 eV. Density functional theory ( DFT ) calculations was carried out to probe the molecular and electronic properties of the PffBB-n polymer by means of B3LYP / 6-311+(d,p) as a basis set in a vacuum using the repeating conjugated units of the polymer backbone in which all of the alkyl substitutions were replaced by ethyl groups to reduce the calculation time. Figure 2 displays the optimized molecular conformation and the frontier molecular orbitals of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n. The dihedral angle between the BDT electron - donating unit and the electron - deficient unit was found to be ∼ 26.9 ° in the optimized structure , which is caused by the ethyl substitution on the thienyl ring. The HOMO delocalizes extensively over the π-conjugation framework , whereas the LUMO mainly populated on the benzothiadiazole Article unit. Such frontier molecular orbital electron distribution would greatly enhance efficient intramolecular charge transfer. The electrochemical properties of PffBB-n were determined by cyclic voltammetry. Their results are summarized in Table 2 , and the respective energy levels are delineated in Figure 2d. The HOMO energy levels of PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 were estimated from the onset oxidation potential to be -5.66 , -5.73 , -5.72 , and -5.78 eV , respectively. The corresponding LUMO energy levels were calculated from the HOMO energy level and the onset absorption of polymers in thin films , which were -4.01 , -4.11 , -4.11 , and -4.16 eV , respectively. As a result , the HOMO energy levels of PffBB-n polymers are much lower than that of ITO and their corresponding LUMO energy levels of PffBB-n lied slightly above that of PC71BM. Such energy level alignment would facilitate charge transfer from the donor polymer to the PC71BM acceptor and provide a relatively large difference between the HOMO energy level of donor polymers and the LUMO level of PC71BM , which is important to achieve a large V oc of a solar device. As a result , BHJ PSCs fabricated from these polymers are promising to achieve high device performance. X-Ray Diffraction ( XRD ). X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out to determine the crystallinity of PffBB-n polymers and the XRD spectra are shown in Figure 3. Despite various sizes of alkyl side chains attached , polymers with the same backbone show very similar XRD patterns. The sharp peaks at around 5 ° correspond to the in-plane spacing ( d 1spacing ) between the polymer backbones , whereas the broad peaks lying above 20 ° ( d 2 -spacing ) is characterized as a π-π stacking distance.

Let's think step by step.

1. PffBB-n: This is a polymer material used in the study. It is a conjugated polymer with a repeating unit of BDT (benzodithiophene) electron-donating unit and a benzothiadiazole electron-deficient unit. The alkyl substituents on the thienyl ring can vary, resulting in different polymer versions such as PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16.

2. Ethyl groups: These are alkyl substituents used in the density functional theory (DFT) calculations to replace the original alkyl substituents in the PffBB-n polymer. This replacement reduces calculation time without significantly altering the molecular and electronic properties of the polymer.

3. ITO (Indium Tin Oxide): This is a widely used transparent conducting oxide material in optoelectronic devices. In this study, ITO is mentioned as a reference material for comparing the energy levels of the PffBB-n polymers.

4. PC71BM ([6,6]-Phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester): This is an organic material used as an electron acceptor in organic solar cells. In this study, PC71BM is mentioned as a reference material for comparing the energy levels of the PffBB-n polymers.

5. XRD (X-ray Diffraction): This is a technique used to determine the crystallinity of materials by measuring the diffraction patterns produced by the interaction of X-rays with the material's atomic structure. In this study, XRD is used to determine the crystallinity of the PffBB-n polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. PffBB-n
2. Ethyl groups
3. PC71BM
4. ITO
5. XRD

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PffBB-n |
| Ethyl groups |
| PC71BM |
| ITO |
| XRD |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: In the solid state , the planarity effect and interchain stacking of PffBB-n caused the bathochromic shift of the absorption cut - off to ∼ 780 nm , corresponding to a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.61 eV. Density functional theory ( DFT ) calculations was carried out to probe the molecular and electronic properties of the PffBB-n polymer by means of B3LYP / 6-311+(d,p) as a basis set in a vacuum using the repeating conjugated units of the polymer backbone in which all of the alkyl substitutions were replaced by ethyl groups to reduce the calculation time. Figure 2 displays the optimized molecular conformation and the frontier molecular orbitals of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n. The dihedral angle between the BDT electron - donating unit and the electron - deficient unit was found to be ∼ 26.9 ° in the optimized structure , which is caused by the ethyl substitution on the thienyl ring. The HOMO delocalizes extensively over the π-conjugation framework , whereas the LUMO mainly populated on the benzothiadiazole Article unit. Such frontier molecular orbital electron distribution would greatly enhance efficient intramolecular charge transfer. The electrochemical properties of PffBB-n were determined by cyclic voltammetry. Their results are summarized in Table 2 , and the respective energy levels are delineated in Figure 2d. The HOMO energy levels of PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 were estimated from the onset oxidation potential to be -5.66 , -5.73 , -5.72 , and -5.78 eV , respectively. The corresponding LUMO energy levels were calculated from the HOMO energy level and the onset absorption of polymers in thin films , which were -4.01 , -4.11 , -4.11 , and -4.16 eV , respectively. As a result , the HOMO energy levels of PffBB-n polymers are much lower than that of ITO and their corresponding LUMO energy levels of PffBB-n lied slightly above that of PC71BM. Such energy level alignment would facilitate charge transfer from the donor polymer to the PC71BM acceptor and provide a relatively large difference between the HOMO energy level of donor polymers and the LUMO level of PC71BM , which is important to achieve a large V oc of a solar device. As a result , BHJ PSCs fabricated from these polymers are promising to achieve high device performance. X-Ray Diffraction ( XRD ). X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out to determine the crystallinity of PffBB-n polymers and the XRD spectra are shown in Figure 3. Despite various sizes of alkyl side chains attached , polymers with the same backbone show very similar XRD patterns. The sharp peaks at around 5 ° correspond to the in-plane spacing ( d 1spacing ) between the polymer backbones , whereas the broad peaks lying above 20 ° ( d 2 -spacing ) is characterized as a π-π stacking distance.

Let's think step by step.

1. Planarity effect and interchain stacking: properties of the material PffBB-n in its solid state that affect its optical properties
2. Bathochromic shift of the absorption cut-off to ~780 nm: optical property of PffBB-n
3. Narrow optical band gap of ~1.61 eV: electronic property of PffBB-n
4. Molecular and electronic properties: properties of the PffBB-n polymer
5. Dihedral angle between the BDT electron-donating unit and the electron-deficient unit: molecular property of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n
6. Frontier molecular orbitals: electronic property of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n
7. HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) and LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) energy levels: electronic properties of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n
8. Efficient intramolecular charge transfer: electronic property of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n
9. HOMO energy levels of PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16: electronic property of the PffBB-n polymers
10. LUMO energy levels of PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16: electronic property of the PffBB-n polymers
11. Energy level alignment: electronic property of the PffBB-n polymers and ITO and PC71BM
12. Crystallinity: property of PffBB-n polymers
13. In-plane spacing (d1spacing) between the polymer backbones: structural property of PffBB-n polymers
14. π-π stacking distance: structural property of PffBB-n polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. Bathochromic shift of the absorption cut-off
2. Narrow optical band gap
3. Dihedral angle
4. Frontier molecular orbitals
5. HOMO and LUMO energy levels
6. Efficient intramolecular charge transfer
7. Energy level alignment
8. Crystallinity
9. In-plane spacing (d1spacing)
10. π-π stacking distance.

Paragraph: In the solid state , the planarity effect and interchain stacking of PffBB-n caused the bathochromic shift of the absorption cut - off to ∼ 780 nm , corresponding to a narrow optical band gap of ∼ 1.61 eV. Density functional theory ( DFT ) calculations was carried out to probe the molecular and electronic properties of the PffBB-n polymer by means of B3LYP / 6-311+(d,p) as a basis set in a vacuum using the repeating conjugated units of the polymer backbone in which all of the alkyl substitutions were replaced by ethyl groups to reduce the calculation time. Figure 2 displays the optimized molecular conformation and the frontier molecular orbitals of the ethyl-substituted repeating units of PffBB-n. The dihedral angle between the BDT electron - donating unit and the electron - deficient unit was found to be ∼ 26.9 ° in the optimized structure , which is caused by the ethyl substitution on the thienyl ring. The HOMO delocalizes extensively over the π-conjugation framework , whereas the LUMO mainly populated on the benzothiadiazole Article unit. Such frontier molecular orbital electron distribution would greatly enhance efficient intramolecular charge transfer. The electrochemical properties of PffBB-n were determined by cyclic voltammetry. Their results are summarized in Table 2 , and the respective energy levels are delineated in Figure 2d. The HOMO energy levels of PffBB-10 , PffBB-12 , PffBB-14 , and PffBB-16 were estimated from the onset oxidation potential to be -5.66 , -5.73 , -5.72 , and -5.78 eV , respectively. The corresponding LUMO energy levels were calculated from the HOMO energy level and the onset absorption of polymers in thin films , which were -4.01 , -4.11 , -4.11 , and -4.16 eV , respectively. As a result , the HOMO energy levels of PffBB-n polymers are much lower than that of ITO and their corresponding LUMO energy levels of PffBB-n lied slightly above that of PC71BM. Such energy level alignment would facilitate charge transfer from the donor polymer to the PC71BM acceptor and provide a relatively large difference between the HOMO energy level of donor polymers and the LUMO level of PC71BM , which is important to achieve a large V oc of a solar device. X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out to determine the crystallinity of PffBB-n polymers and the XRD spectra are shown in Figure 3. Despite various sizes of alkyl side chains attached , polymers with the same backbone show very similar XRD patterns. The sharp peaks at around 5 ° correspond to the in-plane spacing ( d 1spacing ) between the polymer backbones , whereas the broad peaks lying above 20 ° ( d 2 -spacing ) is characterized as a π-π stacking distance.

Let's think step by step.

1. Bathochromic shift of the absorption cut-off to ~ 780 nm.
2. Narrow optical band gap of ~ 1.61 eV.
3. Dihedral angle between the BDT electron-donating unit and the electron-deficient unit is ~ 26.9 °.
4. HOMO energy levels of PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16 are -5.66, -5.73, -5.72, and -5.78 eV, respectively.
5. LUMO energy levels of PffBB-10, PffBB-12, PffBB-14, and PffBB-16 are -4.01, -4.11, -4.11, and -4.16 eV, respectively.
6. In-plane spacing (d1spacing) between the polymer backbones is around 5 °.
7. π-π stacking distance (d2spacing) is characterized as broad peaks lying above 20 °.
